headline: Gluten Free Food Market Competitive Analysis Report 2025: Key Players, Company Profiles, Product Developments, Mergers, Strategic Collaborations, and Revenue Forecast Insights
summary: The international gluten-free food market is projected to surge from approximately US$ 7.22 billion in 2025 to an estimated US$ 14.13 billion by 2033, growing at a CAGR of 8.75%. The demand is driven by increased awareness of celiac disease, gluten intolerance, and a trend towards healthier lifestyles. Major players like The Hain Celestial Group, ConAgra, and Kraft Heinz are innovating with fortified, plant-based, and clean-label options. Enhanced labeling, e-commerce expansion, and social media

headline: Buffett Bet Big On UnitedHealth Stock In Q2 — Now Berkshire Hathaway Could Be Down Billions
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK)(NYSE:BRK) disclosed a new stake in UnitedHealth Group (NYSE:UNH) in August, but after an initial rally, the stock has since fallen, putting the position underwater. Buffett's Berkshire Bets on UNH Stock A 13F filing from Berkshire Hathaway unveiled the purchase of 5,039,564 UNH shares by the conglomerate in the second quarter, a position that represented one of the largest new buys from the company, then led by Buffett. headline: Greg Abel Signals New Berkshire Era With Kraft Heinz And Sirius XM Shakeup
summary: Greg Abel, in his first major move as Berkshire Hathaway CEO, is considering selling the company’s entire Kraft Heinz stake. Recent SEC filings, Kraft Heinz disclosures, and Berkshire’s board resignations at Kraft Heinz point to an intent to fully exit the investment. Berkshire is also exploring a sale of its position in Sirius XM as the business faces subscriber and competitive pressures. Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK.A), recently trading around $713,000.0 per Class A share, is entering a...

headline: Heinz taps into Super Bowl snack culture with novelty ketchup keg
summary: The KegChup plays on data showing 84% of consumers make their own snacks for the big game, which is the second-biggest food holiday of the year.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: CORRECTIONS Ahmad Ghahreman worked on Cyclic Materials’ technology while he was a professor at Queen’s University. A Technology & Business article on Monday about the company, which Ghahreman founded, incorrectly suggested that he developed Cyclic’s technology in his capacity as a professor.
